6.text:
- Welcome to Insight. Today we are
chatting with Guillaume Dufresnoy,

10.text:
Artistic Director of the Big Apple Circus.
The Big Apple Circus is an award-winning

16.text:
presenter of live family entertainment
that is also dedicated to outreach

20.text:
programs and healthcare facilities and
communities across the nation. Guillaume

24.text:
has generously agreed to share some
of his experience with us.

26.text:
I'd like to thank you
Guillaume, for joining us today.

30.text:
- So the circus is a great topic. It's a
great topic in terms of complexity of

34.text:
management, the complexity of the art, the
diversity of the artists. Let's start

40.text:
talking about how do you create
the art of the circus.

44.text:
- Well, basically what we do is that we
tap into world class artists. And the way

53.text:
that business is organized is that artists
work many years into developing one act,

60.text:
and then with that act they go from circus
to circus. So it's not the other model

68.text:
that some people have in mind of, of
family or small group that stays year

72.text:
after year together and try to do
something different every year. We tap a

78.text:
completely different class of artists. So
the way I usually work is that I pick a

84.text:
director who will come and stage the show.
And with that director, we collaborate on

92.text:
picking the creative team and then a
roster of artists that would fit a theme.

100.text:
We keep it simple. We're not about making
a huge production. We're not about telling

107.text:
very complicated stories. We're really
about delivering in a well-produced

113.text:
way but in an intimate and very direct way
the best possible circus arts.

122.text:
- And you're an arts presenter and so the
process is to create an immersive

127.text:
experience for the audience so that the
art can be presented in a way that creates

134.text:
that sort of concentrated experience
without the complexities perhaps, without

139.text:
the bells and whistles that can sometimes
be so distracting from

144.text:
the art that is being presented
by the artist him/herself.

149.text:
- Yeah absolutely. I think we have three
elements that work for us that we are

153.text:
absolutely attached to. One, we're
performing the round, which gives the

158.text:
sense of the group and the community. You
are with your family watching the show but

163.text:
you also can observe across the ring,
which is only 40 feet. You can observe

169.text:
other members of your community, laughing
at the same time, being in awe at the same

174.text:
time. So that part is really the first
connection. The second connection is

180.text:
that the size of the tent is such that we
preserve intimacy. Nobody is seated more

186.text:
than like 50 feet of the ring, and
compared to some other spectacles, that

192.text:
brings you into the action, no matter
what. And then the third aspect is that as

198.text:
you mentioned, we do not put emphasis on
production gimmicks. We don't put masks on

207.text:
artists. We want to see a human being that
does extraordinary things, but at the same

212.text:
time when you observe that artist, you
know exactly that it's a person who put

217.text:
their pants on this morning
one leg at a time.

220.text:
- So let's move away from the day of the
performance and let's move all the way

225.text:
back in time to when you're just thinking
about a concept. How does that work? How

230.text:
do you arrive at the concepts that you're
putting together? I'm sure you have an

234.text:
annual schedule as a presenter. But how do
you arrive at that germ of the

239.text:
idea and then start to fill
that idea with life?

244.text:
- Well, we just use the time machine that
puts us back three years before, three to

249.text:
four years. But I like to use three years
ahead of time. The idea of a show can come

259.text:
different ways. It's a chicken and
egg kind of question. What I like to

269.text:
start with is with a director, someone
who is not necessarily experienced in

275.text:
directing circus because I like a fresh
look, but also somebody who is interested

280.text:
into getting into the world of circus.
I would not be quite as excited to hire

289.text:
someone who has already a preconceived
idea. "I wanna do my circus over there." I'm

295.text:
much more interested in somebody who says,
"Look, I don't know much about circus. I

299.text:
enjoy it and I have a perception of the
Big Apple Circus and its soul, its

306.text:
character, its mission, all of that. And
is there a way here that we can have a

312.text:
project together?" That's the best way.
Then usually, it's the director who comes

319.text:
up with an idea. It can be fairly vague,
but comes up with an idea. Then we work

326.text:
together, just the director and I on
refining it. I really enjoy taking directors to

334.text:
circus festivals or to other circuses. So
we start to get a sense of what kind of

340.text:
acts we like, what are we pursuing for
that specific production. Then we pick a

345.text: creative team. And as we do this, we write... it's an outline of a show. And

353.text:
it can be a period show, it can be focused
on a location, like we did this year with

359.text:
Times Square.
Focused performance next year will be

365.text:
about metamorphosis, changes, magic. We had
the year before that was really the roots

372.text:
of the American Big Top, 1825. It was a
really period show. Except for one piece

381.text:
of music, we really stayed true to the
period. So this is really the way it

385.text:
works. And because of the way the casting
rhythms are and cycles, I really need

392.text:
to book the acts two years in advance. And
then as soon as we open one show, we start

400.text:
the real production work of the next one.
So those are production meetings but by

404.text:
then, we kind of know what
the show will be.

409.text:
- And it's a scripting process but it's
not prescriptive. It's very interactive.

414.text:
You're shaping together with your
collaborator and then as you start to

419.text:
consider what acts as you cast the show,
those players are also going to have some

427.text:
things to contribute to your
concept as well.

430.text:
- Yeah, what I think is crucial is that we
are not about the theme, we are not about

435.text:
the story, we are not about the director,
we are not about me. We are about the acts.

440.text:
We're about the circus acts. And one thing
that I always really insist on is, with any

447.text:
director, no matter the theme, no matter
the plan, if suddenly we have not booked

453.text:
everybody and I run into a fantastic
circus act that happens

457.text:
to be available,
that act will be in the show.

460.text:
- So it's the frame that is created, but
it's a frame for presenting the acts--

467.text:
- It's about presenting circus acts.
Our audience

469.text:
comes to see circus acts, circus
tricks, circus thrills. There's absolutely

475.text:
no doubt about that. Yes,
we present it well.

478.text:
Yes, we give unity to the production
with music, with costume,

482.text:
with the set, with what
the ring master will say.

485.text:
And we're very proud of that, I don't want
to diminish. But ultimately,

489.text: we are about the circus tricks.

493.text:
- And every show is a risk. Every show,
there is a threat of failure. Because if

499.text:
you're just repeating what constantly was
successful in the past, you can be sure

504.text:
of one thing, you won't necessarily be
the thing that's embraced in the future.

507.text:
- Well, one of the challenges that we have
at the Big Apple Circus is that we have a

512.text:
very high rate of return. We have families
who come in year after year. I think 60 or

519.text:
70% of our audience has seen the show in
the last two years. So one of the elements

527.text:
of quality that we bring is not only the
quality of this production but it's only

530.text:
the fact that it's completely different
from the past ones and the next one will

536.text:
be completely different as well. So, it's
really coming up with brand new concept

541.text:
every year. And that's why it's so
important to have different creative teams

548.text:
to bring you that kind of inspiration year
in and year out.

553.text:
- And you also have full-time artists on
staff. You have your musicians, you have

558.text:
others who are going to be on your staff
and part of your team show after show. How

565.text:
do you make the decision what
competencies, what qualities you want to

570.text:
retain on staff, and what qualities you
would like to bring

573.text:
in and refresh show
after show after show?

576.text:
- Well, what I think, yes, the band is
pretty much set, although they have substitutes,

580.text:
but the musical director is a key element
of the team. And we're fortunate that he

586.text:
has been here for years and hopefully will
stay for many more. As far as the artists,

593.text:
there has been an evolution in the history
of the Big Apple Circus. There was really

599.text:
a fairly large number of core company
members... we have up to five or

607.text:
seven. That way year after year and
practicing new acts and

613.text:
I have taken a slightly
different direction with this.

619.text:
Because it's absolutely impossible for
performers to develop every year a

627.text:
different act that technically is of the
same level as someone

631.text:
who spends five or ten
years developing one act.

635.text:
And the standards have certainly evolved
with the access to the internet. Anybody

641.text:
can look at the best circus acts in the
world. So you're facing an audience that

647.text:
knows the business very well, and to be
able to really bring the best and amaze

653.text:
that audience I need to bring the best
possible performers, the best possible

658.text:
acts that have been developed. So the path
that I have chosen for now is that I'm

664.text:
keeping the ringmaster as a recognizable
character and he's under contract for

670.text:
several years now and our animal trainer
is also staying on a multi-year contract,

676.text:
although she has the charge of coming up
with different acts every year. And what

682.text:
I'm aiming at is finding the right balance
between familiarity

689.text:
and new and exciting and high-level acts.
And that's the path that I'm trying now,

697.text: and let's see how that works.

700.text:
- So you end up with a flexibly
configurable refreshed experience that

705.text:
allows your jaded audience to not be jaded
because they are those that have purchased

710.text:
tickets for the last three years are going
to come back this year and see something

714.text:
new. They'll see new performers, a
refreshed sensibility and perhaps things

720.text:
- Hopefully things they have
never seen before.

723.text:
And at the same time, they will have the
pleasure of seeing John Kennedy Kane or

728.text:
Jen Yvette Bell again and they will, "Oh,
great! Look at what she did this year

732.text:
compared to what she did last year."
That creates

736.text:
another level of connection,
that familiarity.

739.text:
- What is the interaction between the arts
side and the business side like? Because

745.text:
you are going to be to a certain extent
dependent on ticket sales and financial

752.text:
management and budgets
and all those things.

755.text:
- Well, I think the one thing that's very
important is that being not-for-profit,

761.text:
the Big Apple Circus is very attached to
the quality of its programs, all of them.

767.text:
The unit production as well as the
community programs. And the means to put

776.text:
together the best possible programs, or
really finding those means is really a

781.text:
priority. The way we function, I'm an
equal to the Executive Director Lynn

786.text:
Stirrup and together we really manage the
organization and set the objectives

795.text:
working with the board at the governance
level. The budget is pretty much set quite

801.text:
a bit in advance because of the same
difficult times that everybody has had in

807.text:
the arts. Budgets have been flat in the
last few years.

811.text:
- Plus you have a three-year planning
cycle as well.

813.text:
- Plus you have a three-year planning
cycle. But I have been fortunate once

817.text:
again that the Board has been absolutely
100% behind not cutting the production

824.text:
budget and not cutting the program budget
either, because everybody believes in the

830.text:
mission. And I think that would be a huge
difference in the for-profit world,

833.text: my budget would have been slashed.

835.text:
- How did you get to the point where
you're undertaking this task at this time

841.text:
of your career?
Talk about your own career trajectory and

844.text:
your own evolution as an artist and as an
arts presenter.

847.text:
- Well, I came to the circus by accident.
Basically, my first girlfriend, who was my

856.text:
high-school sweetheart, you would say
here, was a gymnast and a circus

860.text:
aficionado, and when I left the French
Navy I went to live with her in Paris and

865.text:
it was really a good ol' Gypsy life. And
she introduced me to a place where a

874.text:
retired circus performer was training
people on trapeze. And it's that gentleman

879.text:
who kind of out of, not kind of completely
out of the blue came up to me one day and

887.text:
say, "Hey, you don't wanna put an act
together? Your girlfriend is in a circus

890.text:
school." And I was like, "Moi?"
- Moi?

894.text:
- And so I said, "You know, you're 21. You
think you'll never die." So I said, "All

899.text:
right. I'll try." And that's how I got
into the business. I created a few years

905.text:
later, it was a different girl, we don't
want that story,

908.text:
a different area and act, and it was
that second act, I was a catcher,

913.text:
that Paul Binder saw us work at
the French National Circus and hired us.

921.text:
So I came to the States in 1987. It was my
rigging of partner in a three-months

927.text:
contract to work for the Big Apple
Circus, and they have

931.text: never gotten rid of me since then.

933.text:
- So talk about the work that you do on
healthcare facilities and then

939.text:
- So basically, the idea is that the live
performance of circus arts does not need

946.text:
to be necessarily in the ring. And what
happens in the ring, the same direct

952.text:
performance, the same contact, the same
respect from the audience, the same level

957.text:
of skills, we bring in other places.
So we have developed a group of

964.text:
professional hospital clowns that work at
the moment in 14 pediatric hospitals

972.text:
nationwide. And basically, we spearheaded
the profession of hospital clowning. It

978.text:
was Michael Christiansen who came up with
the idea. And we have become specialists

986.text:
at it. What's very interesting is that,
and I like to go on clowning rounds with

992.text:
them just to see the work and to see the
environment and to see the impact.

999.text:
So these performers have their
artist skills but they also train in tons

1006.text:
of hospital procedure, hygiene, patient
privacy, tons of things. And then they are

1013.text:
facing an audience that is in a very tough
setting and who has not chosen to come see

1023.text:
them but the clowns are there and they
show up. And the first thing they do is

1031.text:
they ask permission to come into the room
because it's probably the only time that

1036.text:
week that the kid who is a patient is
empowered to say yes or no to anything.

1043.text:
And once they get a yes, the second
wonderful ability that they have is what

1052.text:
we call "read the room." And they feel
very rapidly what the energy is

1057.text:
from the kid, from the nurse, from the
parents and they adapt and react and go

1067.text:
with that. And it's never an in-your-face
performance, "This is what I do." This is,

1074.text:
"How about this?" "How about that?" and if
it doesn't work, we step back and always

1080.text:
with aiming at, again, a connection
and a skill.

1088.text:
- It's a real dialogue and you empower the
kid, which remain absolutely crucial. But

1094.text:
in the course of one round, when maybe the
clowns visit 10, 15 rooms, they reach so

1103.text:
many people. Because you reach all the
parents, all the staff and if you walk

1109.text:
behind him, you see, you know, the
security guard who is really bored on his

1113.text:
chair, and the person who is cleaning the
rooms and is having a hard time and

1119.text:
suddenly they pay attention. They listen
to the clown. They get a smile. It

1124.text:
completely changes. It transforms the
atmosphere of the floor so quickly.

1130.text:
- What is in store for the Big Apple
Circus over the next years?

1134.text:
- Well, what I think is we have a great
know-how, both on the production side and

1143.text:
on the community program side. So the
dream is to really bring that know-how to

1150.text:
more places. Our community programs are
very scalable. All of them can be

1157.text:
developed easily, not at a very high
cost and in many locations.

1163.text:
- Very high impact. I think it's a very
high return for not a huge investment, for

1171.text:
a high reward for our funder. On the
production side, we will remain with one

1178.text:
Big Top and one main production, but we are
really looking at opportunities to bring

1186.text:
the same kind of production with the same
qualities to different venues. It could

1193.text:
be a theater. We put a show a few years
ago in Abu Dhabi in a huge convention

1200.text:
center and we were able, just by the
layout of the place, to bring the intimacy

1205.text:
back and present circus acts and circus arts
the way these audience have never seen.

1212.text:
So I think I'm really excited about other
opportunities where we remain ourselves

1218.text:
but simply do it inside the
different venues.

1221.text:
- With an unconstrained vision and
unconstrained joy, Guillaume Dufresnoy,

1226.text:
thank you so much for sharing your
experience with us, for sharing the Big

1231.text:
Apple Circus with us, and thank you so
much for your insights.

1234.text:
- You're very welcome. I love talking
about it.
